main.title: Welcome to Pathways
main.description: This guide will help you navigate your options in Germany. Whether you want to earn money, continue your education, or learn German, we have resources and step-by-step guidance for you. Choose the path that best fits your current situation and goals.

tips.explore_multiple_paths: You can explore multiple paths - they are not mutually exclusive

tips.take_your_time: Take your time to read through each option before deciding

earn_money.title: Earn Money â€“ Work & Career
earn_money.description: You want to earn money or gain your first work experience, but you are not yet sure which profession suits you? Here you will find pathways into work and careers â€“ even without a perfect school certificate or with limited German skills. Whether it is a job, apprenticeship, internship or voluntary service: there are more options than you might think. We show you where to start and which steps make sense.

tips.no_need_for_plan: You do not need a perfect plan right away. Many paths begin with trying things out.
tips.practical_experience: Practical experience often matters more than certificates, especially at the beginning.
tips.german_skills: German language skills improve significantly through work and practical experience.
tips.low_age_opportunity: Even at the age of 16 or 17, there are legal opportunities to work or prepare for a career.

tips.without_contract: Be careful with offers without a contract or with cash payment.
tips.private_offers: Always check private offers to see whether costs apply.
tips.if_unsure: If you are unsure: get advice first (e.g. Jobcenter, Youth Employment Agency). Counselling is free â€“ use it!

demand_in_mv.title: Which professions are in demand in MV?
demand_in_mv.description: Where you live makes a difference. Every region needs different professions. This gives you opportunities - even without perfect school grades. In Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania, practical professions are particularly sought after: e.g. skilled trades, nursing, gastronomy, or logistics. Here you can find out which professions are really needed in your area and where you can get an apprenticeship, internship, or entry-level position more quickly. You don't have to commit "forever." First look, try things out, gain experience > then decide.

bop_internship.title: Career Exploration Internship (BOP)
bop_internship.description: A short internship to try out a profession. You spend a few weeks in a company to see if the job fits you. You gain practical experience in a company and receive support from the Employment Agency or Job Center.

tips.duration: The internship lasts between 1 and 6 weeks. It can be extended to a maximum of 6 weeks.
tips.free_participation: Participation in the career orientation internship is free of charge.
tips.remuneration_costs: As a rule, no remuneration is paid. BUT: Travel or accommodation costs can be covered if necessary. Apply to the Jobcenter or Employment Agency to have your costs covered!
tips.prerequisites: The prerequisite is that compulsory schooling has been completed and you are not currently attending school.
tips.jobcenter_approval: Important: ALWAYS get the job center involved beforehand! They can check and decide what help you can get! That's why the internship can only start after approval by the job center or employment agency.

bvj_program.title: Pre-Vocational School Program (BVJ)
bvj_program.description: The Vocational Preparation Year (BVJ) is a one-year school programme for young people who do not yet have an apprenticeship or a clear career perspective. It combines lessons at a vocational school with practical work experience in companies. For young people who have recently migrated and have limited German skills, there is a specialised language-focused version called BVJ-S. The exact rules may vary slightly depending on the federal state. For detailed information, contact a vocational school or career counselling service.

tips.language_focus: Especially helpful if German skills are not yet sufficient for vocational training. Language learning and practical experience are well combined in BVJ-S.
tips.daz_central: German as a Second Language (DaZ) is the central focus of the programme. Ask specifically about intensive DaZ lessons if your German level is still low.
tips.compulsory_schooling: Regular attendance is important - BVJ-S is subject to compulsory schooling.
tips.internships_help: Internships help with career orientation and improve everyday language skills.
tips.start_early: Starting early pays off â€“ better German makes everyday life and training easier.
tips.parents_involved: Parents or guardians should be involved early in the process.

bvj_s_program.title: Pre-Vocational School Program with Language Focus (BVJ-S)
bvj_s_program.description: The Vocational Preparation Year with Language Focus (BVJ-S) is a school-based programme at vocational schools in Germany. It is designed for newly arrived young people who have limited German language skills. The main goal of the BVJ-S is to improve German language skills and to support career orientation. Alongside language learning, students gain basic knowledge about working life and different professions. The programme combines intensive German as a second language (DaZ) lessons with practical activities and vocational orientation. Students can take part in practical training phases (internships) and learn how school, training and work in Germany function. The BVJ-S is a full-time educational programme and usually lasts one school year, depending on language level. It helps prepare students for the next step, such as vocational training, further schooling or other educational pathways.

tips.language_focus_help: Especially helpful if German skills are not yet sufficient for vocational training.
tips.combination: Language learning and practical experience are well combined in BVJ-S.
tips.daz_focus: German as a Second Language (DaZ) is the central focus of the programme.
tips.intensive_lessons: Ask specifically about intensive DaZ lessons if your German level is still low.
tips.attendance: Regular attendance is important â€“ BVJ-S is subject to compulsory schooling.
tips.internships: Internships help with career orientation and improve everyday language skills.
tips.start_early: Starting early pays off â€“ better German makes everyday life and training easier.
tips.parents: Parents or guardians should be involved early in the process.

bvb_program.title: Career Preparation Program (BvB)
bvb_program.description: The Vocational Preparation Programme (BVB) is an offer provided by the Federal Employment Agency for young people under the age of 25. It supports career orientation, preparation for vocational training or direct entry into work. The programme is carried out by certified training providers and can also include the opportunity to obtain a lower secondary school certificate.

tips.target_group: Suitable if you do not yet have an apprenticeship or clear career plan.
tips.no_certificate_needed: Possible even without a school certificate.
tips.combination: Combines learning, practice and career orientation.
tips.internships: Several internships help you try out different professions.
tips.get_certificate: A school certificate can often be obtained during the programme.
tips.flexibility: The programme is flexible and adapted to individual needs.

eq_internship.title: Pre-Apprenticeship Internship (EQ)
eq_internship.description: Pre-Apprenticeship Internship (EQ) is a programme run by the Employment Agency and works like an extended internship in a company (6-12 months). You work like a trainee and often get an apprenticeship afterwards.

tips.duration: An entry qualification lasts at least 6 months and up to a maximum of 12 months.
tips.transition: A transition into an apprenticeship is possible at any time.
tips.schedule: The EQ usually takes place full-time, but can also be completed part-time if needed.
tips.eligibility: Participation is only possible if you have not yet completed a vocational qualification or a degree.
tips.school_obligation: If you are subject to compulsory vocational school attendance, attending vocational school remains mandatory.
tips.allowance: During the EQ, you receive a monthly allowance of â‚¬276 funded by the Employment Agency.
tips.costs: Travel costs may be covered; the company may voluntarily top up the allowance.
tips.restriction: Important: Entry qualifications are only possible for company-based training, not for school-based vocational training.

dual_apprenticeship.title: Apprenticeship (Dual System)
dual_apprenticeship.description: In the dual system, you work in a company and attend a vocational school at the same time. You earn money while learning a profession from scratch. It usually lasts 3 to 3.5 years. You receive a trainee salary (AusbildungsvergÃ¼tung) that increases each year.

tips.german_level: You don't have to speak perfect German to start; many companies support you if you show commitment.
tips.motivation_over_grades: Many employers value motivation, reliability, and practical interest more than perfect school grades.
tips.internships_impact: Previous internships or entry-level qualifications (EQ) significantly increase your chances of getting a contract.
tips.application_help: Don't do it alone â€“ get help with your resume from job centers or school counseling services.
tips.labor_shortage: Look for 'shortage occupations' (Mangelberufe) â€“ the chances for an apprenticeship are particularly high there.
tips.take_your_time: Take your time to find out which profession really suits your talents.
tips.parallel_channels: Use multiple channels: online portals, apprenticeship exchanges, and direct contact with local companies.
tips.networking: Networking pays off â€“ talk to family, friends, and teachers about your plans.
tips.training_fairs: Visit training fairs (Ausbildungsmessen) to talk directly to potential employers.

school_certificate.title: School Certificate (Catch up / Upgrade)
school_certificate.description: You do not yet have a school certificate or would like to achieve a higher qualification? In Germany, there are many ways to catch up on or improve a school certificate â€“ even if you had to leave school, are new to Germany or are still learning German. Here you will find an overview of the most important pathways and support options.

tips.after_compulsory: A school certificate can also be obtained after compulsory schooling has ended.
tips.get_advice: Getting advice before you start saves time and helps avoid detours.
tips.language_improvement: German language skills can be improved alongside completing a school certificate.
tips.free_programs: Many programmes are free of charge or publicly funded.
tips.consider_pathways: It is normal to consider several pathways before making a decision.
tips.private_costs: Important: Private offers may involve costs â€“ always check in advance.

lower_secondary_certificate.title: Lower secondary school certificate (Berufsreife)
lower_secondary_certificate.description: The 'Regionale Schule' is not a separate school typeâ€”the final certificate depends on your performance. The basic school certificate (Berufsreife) is an officially recognised German school qualification after grade 9. It is usually the minimum requirement to start vocational training (Ausbildung).

tips.not_immediate: You don't have to finish your school certificate immediately. Many people first start with a vocational preparation year (BVJ), an internship, or a job â€” and complete the certificate later.
tips.get_later: If you didn't finish school, that's not a problem. In Germany you can still get a school certificate later â€” in several ways: BVJ, vocational school, evening school, external exams.
tips.ukraine_recognition: If you already have a Ukrainian school certificate, it can often be officially recognised.

intermediate_certificate.title: Intermediate secondary school certificate
intermediate_certificate.description: The Intermediate secondary school certificate (formerly Realschulabschluss) is a medium-level school qualification in Germany. In Mecklenburg-Vorpommern it is usually completed after grade 10 at a Regional School or a comprehensive school. With this certificate you can: start a vocational training (apprenticeship), attend further vocational schools and, with good grades, later continue to the Abitur (university entrance qualification).

tips.performance_decides: A "Regional School" is not a special school type â€” your performance decides the certificate you get.
tips.attendance_matters: If you are still in school: attendance and participation matter a lot.
tips.key_subjects: Focus especially on German, Maths and English â€” they are key subjects in the final exams.
tips.ukraine_recognition: If you already have a Ukrainian school certificate, it may be officially recognised in Germany.
tips.parallel_learning: You do not have to do everything at once â€” language learning and school qualification can run in parallel.

remote_school.title: Remote secondary school
remote_school.description: Distance learning means you study from home at your own pace. You receive materials online or by mail and have access to tutors for support. This is a great option if you need to work, care for family, or live far from a physical school. Important: Unlike public adult education centers, distance learning usually involves fees, but you can often get financial support.

abitur.title: Abitur / University entrance qualification
abitur.description: The Abitur is the highest school certificate in Germany. It gives you a general university entrance qualification â€” you can study at any university or college. Normally students get the Abitur at a Gymnasium (grade 12 or 13). But you can also complete it later as an adult (second education pathway). The final exam includes several written and oral exams. You do not always have to return to normal school â€” there are different options depending on your situation.

tips.study_fields: The Abitur is important if you want to study (e.g. IT, medicine, engineering, teaching).
tips.language_skills: You usually need good German skills (about B2â€“C1 level).
tips.pathway_options: Typical options: Adult college (full-time school), Evening high school (part-time while working), Distance learning school (study from home), External examination (self-study, only exams).
tips.self_check: Honestly check your level (German and Math are key).
tips.pros_cons: Adult college = fastest but full-time; Evening school = good if you work; Distance learning = flexible but requires discipline; External exam = hardest option.
tips.learning_aids: Use learning apps, videos and AI explanations.
tips.restart_help: Adult education courses help a lot when restarting learning.

evening_school_vhs.title: Evening school for adults / adult education centre (VHS)
evening_school_vhs.description: A Volkshochschule (VHS) is an adult education centre. Attendance is voluntary. You learn in small groups and can choose from many different courses. There are school classes in the afternoon/evening for language learning and school certificate preparation while you work at daytime or attend courses.

tips.where_to_get_advice: Where can I get advice? You can get information and personal guidance directly at your local adult education centre (VHS).
tips.offered_courses: What courses are offered? VHS centres offer many types of courses: German language courses, hobby and interest courses (cooking, sports, art) and school certificates: lower secondary certificate (Hauptschule level), intermediate secondary certificate (Realschule level).
tips.when_classes_take_place: When do classes take place? This depends on the centre and the course. Most courses are available in the morning and afternoon/evening. The best option: contact the VHS near you and ask.
tips.cost_info: How much does it cost? Fees vary depending on the course, the VHS centre and the federal state. There is no fixed price â€” always check in advance.

steps.goto_have_idea: I have a plan â€“ show me how to start my career/training.

external_candidate_exam.title: External candidate examination
external_candidate_exam.description: The external candidate exam lets you earn an official school certificate without attending a regular school full-time.

tips.certificates_available: You can get: lower secondary certificate, intermediate certificate, or Abitur (depending on preparation and level).
tips.preparation_methods: Preparation is mostly self-study. Distance schools, adult education centers (VHS), or private tutors can support you.
tips.be_realistic: Be realistic: you need a learning plan and regular study time every week.
tips.use_ai: Use AI tools to understand topics, compare subjects, and practice exam questions.
tips.application_deadline: You must apply for admission (usually before 15 January of the exam year).

steps.goto_have_idea: After the exam: I know exactly what I want to study/work.

college_prep_adults.title: College-prep school for adults / evening grammar school
college_prep_adults.description: These are special schools for adults who want to get the German Abitur (university entrance qualification) later in life. You do not need to go back to a normal high school. There are two main versions: 'Kolleg' (full-time during the day, like a normal school, takes 2-3 years) and 'Abendgymnasium' (classes in the evening so you can work during the day, takes 3-4 years). After finishing, you can study at a university or start higher-level vocational training.

tips.common_pathway: This path is very common in Germany â€” many adults do their Abitur at 20-30 years old.
tips.prerequisites: You usually need the intermediate school certificate (Realschulabschluss/Mittlere Reife) first.
tips.german_improvement: Schools often help with German improvement while you study.
tips.financial_support: You may be eligible for student financial support (BAfÃ¶G!).
tips.studienkolleg_distinction: Don't confuse it with 'Studienkolleg' â€” that is for foreign students before university, not for Abitur.

steps.goto_have_idea: I'm getting the Abitur because I have a specific study/job goal.

steps.contact_school: Contact a nearby evening school or Kolleg and ask for a counseling appointment. Ask if BAfÃ¶G funding is possible.

steps.language_check: If your German is still weak, choose a language course first (integration course or BSK).

have_idea.title: I have an idea/ a wish what I`d like to do - but how to get there?
have_idea.description: You already have an idea what you would like to do â€” that's great. Now the question is: what do you need to get there? Many careers in Germany follow clear steps (training -> work -> further qualification). Sometimes your goal is correct, but the path is different than expected. You might need a school certificate before you can start training. In Germany you often learn a job through dual training (company + vocational school). If your German is not strong yet, this does not mean you must give up the goal. You don't have to choose perfectly â€” you only need the next realistic step. You can change direction later. Many people do.

tips.check_requirements: Find out whether the job requires training, school, or a specific certificate.
tips.real_examples: Look up real examples: how did other people enter this job?
tips.compare_professions: Compare at least two similar professions.
tips.cert_check: Ask: Do I need Realschule, intermediate certificate, or Abitur?
tips.start_early: Search for training positions early (1 year ahead).
tips.prep_programs: You can start with preparation programs or language courses.
tips.ask_counselors: Ask teachers, social workers or counselors to check your plan.
tips.use_ai: Use AI tools to understand job tasks or to practice applications.

ukrainian_school_qualification.title: Ukrainian school qualification
ukrainian_school_qualification.description: After 9 years of schooling you receive a certificate comparable to the German lower secondary school certificate (Berufsreife/Hauptschulabschluss). After 11 years of schooling you obtain a Ukrainian school-leaving certificate that gives access to university in Ukraine and can USUALLY be recognised in Germany at least at the level of the intermediate secondary certificate (Mittlere Reife/Realschulabschluss). You want to obtain or complete a Ukrainian school certificate, even if you currently live in Germany? There are ways to continue the Ukrainian school pathway online or externally and obtain a state-recognised Ukrainian certificate. This pathway can be useful if you want to continue studying in Ukraine later or use a Ukrainian certificate for recognition procedures.

tips.decide_location: Decide first: University in Germany or in Ukraine?
tips.check_license: It is important that the school is officially state-licensed (check accreditation). Verify the school in EDEBO registry.
tips.ausbildung_vs_uni: If planning Ausbildung -> German school certificate may be more useful than a Ukrainian one.
tips.recognition_procedure: For Ukrainian certificates a recognition procedure for Germany may be required.
tips.abitur_warning: Attention: An 11-year Ukrainian certificate does NEVER automatically equal German Abitur!!

supplementary_classes.title: Supplementary classes
supplementary_classes.description: Supplementary classes (Ukrainian education component) are additional online lessons offered by a Ukrainian school while the student attends a regular German school. They do not replace regular schooling. In these supplementary classes, students mainly learn Ukrainian language, Ukrainian literature, and the history of Ukraine. Sometimes other subjects from the Ukrainian curriculum are also taught. These classes help students keep their Ukrainian language skills, reduce the learning load because not all subjects have to be studied twice, and can help with the recognition of school results. This type of learning can be useful for students who want to receive a Ukrainian school certificate.

tips.recognition_not_automatic: The recognition of grades does not happen automatically. Each [case needs verification].
tips.check_official_status: Make sure that the school is officially recognized by the state and is allowed to issue official Ukrainian school certificates.

links.school_list: List of schools that can offer supplementary classes.

steps.ask_about_subjects: Before you sign up, ask by email if subjects from a German school can be accepted.
steps.collect_reports: Collect and keep all German grade reports.

distance_learning.title: Distance learning
distance_learning.description: Distance learning is a recognized form of education in Ukraine, even though classes do not take place at school. In distance learning, students take part in online classes on a regular basis. There is a fixed timetable. Assignments and tests are given regularly. The time required is similar to regular school education.

tips.contact_previous_school: Contact your previous school in Ukraine by email or phone and ask if they offer this option.
tips.attend_current_or_other: You can attend distance learning at your current school or at another school that offers distance learning.
tips.german_attendance_rules: Distance learning from Ukraine does not always automatically replace school attendance in Germany. It is important to discuss your type of schooling with your German school.

external_schooling.title: External schooling
external_schooling.description: External schooling is an officially recognized type of education in Ukraine. You do not need to attend regular lessons. Instead, you study most of the subjects on your own. You mainly contact the school for tests, exams, and the final yearly evaluation.

tips.flexible_learning: Flexible and self-directed learning is possible.
tips.stay_connected: You stay connected to the Ukrainian school system.
tips.official_certificates: You receive officially recognized Ukrainian school certificates.
tips.combine_abroad: It is possible to combine school abroad with a Ukrainian school.
tips.less_time: You need less time because there are no regular classes.
tips.online_platforms: Using free online learning platforms like the All-Ukrainian Online School makes learning easier.

links.lms_eschool: Official Ukrainian online learning platform 'All-Ukrainian Online School'.
links.mon_gov: Official website of the Ukrainian Ministry of Education.

steps.recognition_process: Plan the official recognition of your certificate in Germany.
steps.choose_school: Choose a Ukrainian school that offers external learning. Not every school offers this.
steps.email_admin: Write an email to the school administration and ask to be enrolled in the external study program.
steps.prepare_docs: Prepare the documents. For enrollment, you usually need an application, a copy of the birth certificate or passport, and, if available, documents from your previous schooling.

private_schools.title: Private schools
private_schools.description: Private schools are schools that are not fully paid by the government. You can get the same German school certificates at many private schools (Hauptschule, Realschule, sometimes Abitur). Some private schools are helpful for students who had problems in public school (language, moving countries, gaps in education). Many private schools offer support classes, German language help or smaller groups.

tips.prices_vary: Prices are very different. Some schools cost about 50 â‚¬ per month.
tips.not_easier: Important: A private school does NOT automatically make school easier. You still need to learn and pass exams.
tips.check_recognition: Always check if the school is officially recognised by the state. Otherwise the certificate may not be valid.
tips.beware_contracts: Beware of contracts: some schools require long-term payment even if you leave.

steps.recognition_process: Plan the official recognition of your certificate in Germany.
steps.search_compare: Look for private schools in your area and compare them.
steps.check_certificate_need: Check which school certificate you actually need for your future (Ausbildung or university).
steps.contact_school: Talk to the school directly and ask: costs, timetable, language support and exams.
steps.check_contract: Before signing a contract, show it to a social worker, teacher or advisor.

recognition_certificates.title: Recognition of certificates
recognition_certificates.description: A school certificate from another country can be recognized in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern as lower secondary school leaving certificate (Berufsreife) or intermediate school leaving certificate (Mittlere Reife). To do this, you must show that you successfully completed at least ten years at a general school. Your school certificate must also include grades in important subjects, such as your mother tongue, a foreign language, mathematics, a science subject, and a social studies subject. In Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, the Ministry for Education and Childcare is responsible for recognizing school certificates.

tips.application_method: The application for recognition must be sent by post (not by email). The application does not need a special form.
tips.incomplete_apps: Incomplete applications are the most common reason for long waiting times. It is better to submit too many documents than too few.
tips.official_certification: Make sure that all copies are officially certified.
tips.translation_requirement: School certificates from abroad must be translated into German by an official translator.
tips.cost_coverage: The costs for translations can be covered by the Jobcenter or the Employment Agency under certain conditions.

links.mv_info: Information about the recognition of foreign school certificates in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.

steps.goto_have_idea: I have a plan â€“ how do I start training or work now?

steps.ask_funding: Ask in advance if Jobcenter or Employment Agency can pay for the translation.
steps.translate_docs: Have all documents officially translated into German by a sworn translator.
steps.certify_copies: Have copies of all documents officially certified.
steps.send_post: Send the application for recognition together with all documents by post to the Ministry for Education and Childcare.

learn_german.title: Learn German
learn_german.description: Good German language skills are the key to school, vocational training and work in Germany. There are many ways to learn German - in courses, online or in everyday life. Here you will find an overview of useful ways to improve your German skills, no matter which level you start at.

tips.practice_over_grammar: Language is learned through practice - not only through grammar.
tips.combine_life_courses: Courses and everyday life can be combined well.
tips.free_offers: Many offers are free of charge or publicly funded.
tips.start_early: Even with limited German, it is worth starting early.
tips.work_improves_skills: German often improves faster when you work, do an internship or attend school.
tips.imperfect_okay: Good to know: You do not need to speak perfect German to take the next step.
tips.use_ai: Use AI to have texts explained or corrected for you.

links.vhs_portal: The vhs learning portal offers suitable online German courses for self-study at different levels (A1â€“B2). No prior knowledge of German is required. The offer is free of charge.
links.goethe_institute: The Goethe-Institut provides exercises for self-study of German. Exercises are available for all language levels (A1â€“C2). Registration is recommended but not required.

integration_courses.title: Integration courses
integration_courses.description: Integration courses help people who are new to Germany to learn German and find their way in everyday life. They consist of a language course and an orientation course covering history, culture, laws and daily life in Germany. Integration courses are organised by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) and are offered by approved education providers.

tips.course_structure: An integration course always consists of a language course and an orientation course.
tips.placement_test: A placement test is carried out before the course starts to find the right level.
tips.course_types: There are different types of courses: general courses, special courses and intensive courses.
tips.attendance_mode: Courses can be attended full-time or part-time.
tips.ukrainian_refugees: Ukrainian refugees are not automatically obliged to attend, but may be required to participate.
tips.costs_fee: Participation is usually subject to a fee. Exemption from costs is possible under certain conditions.
tips.fee_exemption: Important: A fee exemption must be applied for - it does not apply automatically.

links.bamf_info: Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
links.bamf_finder: Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) - Finding integration courses.

steps.apply_admission: Apply for admission to an integration course.

job_related_courses.title: Job-related Language Courses (BSK)
job_related_courses.description: Job-related language courses (BSK) help people with a refugee or migration background to improve their German language skills specifically for the workplace. They build on integration courses and are funded by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF). The aim is to support entry into training, employment or everyday working life through targeted language learning.

tips.b1_requirement: Job-related language courses usually require German language skills at least at B1 level at entry.
tips.course_variety: There are courses with certificate examinations (A2-C2) and workplace-related courses.
tips.format_options: Job-related language courses can take place in person or online.
tips.flexibility: Courses are available as full-time or part-time alongside employment.
tips.cost_rules: Participation is free of charge up to an annual taxable income of â‚¬20,000. If income is higher, a contribution may be required (can be covered by employer).
tips.participation_permit: Important: Check if you can get a participation permit â€” you cannot register without it. Available at Jobcenter, Employment Agency or migration counseling.

links.bamf_general: Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) â€“ Job-related language courses.

steps.contact_authority: First go to the Jobcenter, Employment Agency or a migration counseling office (MBE/MD) and ask for a job-related German course.
steps.check_permit: They will check if you can get a participation permit. If your German is below B1, you will usually be sent to an integration course first.
steps.choose_school: With the permit, choose a language school (course provider) near you.
steps.bring_docs: Bring your documents: residence permit, registration certificate (Anmeldung), school or work certificates.
steps.placement_test: The school will do a placement test and assign you to the right level (A2, B1, B2 or C1).
steps.attend_regularly: Wait for the course to start (often 2-6 weeks) and attend regularly â€” missing classes can cause problems with benefits.
steps.final_exam: After the course you take an official exam (telc or DTB) -> very important for training or employment.

vhs_learning_platform.title: VHS-learning platform
vhs_learning_platform.description: A Volkshochschule (VHS) is an adult education centre. Attendance is voluntary. Classes are in groups and there are many different courses. Besides language courses there are hobby courses (cooking, sports, art) and you can also earn their intermediate certificate (Realschulabschluss) or lower secondary certificate (Hauptschulabschluss). Classes depend on the centre and the course. Most offer morning and afternoon classes â€” ask directly at the centre. Fees vary depending on the course, centre and federal state. There is no single fixed price.

tips.advice: Where can I get advice? You can get information and personal counselling at your local adult education centre.
tips.language_interest: Interested in language courses? Check the sections Integration Course, Job-related Language Courses and Learn German.
tips.school_certificate: Do you want to gain or catch up a school certificate? See the sections Hauptschulabschluss, Realschulabschluss and Abitur. The section 'second-chance education' explains alternative ways.

steps.find_nearest: Find your nearest VHS. Use the school finder and choose the closest adult education centre. Check the courses page of that centre.
steps.book_appointment: Book a counselling appointment. Call, email or visit the office hours ('Beratung' / 'Sprechzeit'). Ask which course fits your level and your goal (job, training or certificate).
steps.take_test: Take a placement test. Most VHS offer a short German test. This decides whether you start with Integration course, B1/B2 or job language course.
steps.choose_goal: Choose your goal. Decide ONE first step: Learn German for daily life, prepare for training (Ausbildung), catch up a school certificate.
steps.register_course: Register for a course. Bring: ID/passport, residence permit (if available), jobcenter/agentur letter (if you have one).
steps.check_funding: Check funding. Ask: Jobcenter / Employment Agency, BAMF eligibility. Many participants pay nothing.
steps.start_routine: Start learning routine. Attend regularly, use homework + online learning (apps, VHS Lernportal), ask teachers about next course level.
steps.plan_next: Plan the next step early. Already during the course ask: internship, training preparation (BvB/BVJ), school certificate courses.

apps_private_offers.title: Apps & private offers
apps_private_offers.description: In addition to public and officially recognised language courses, there are many apps and private offers that can help you practise German. These tools are useful for practice, but they usually do not replace an official language course.

tips.supplement_course: Well suited as a supplement to a course or school.
tips.watch_costs: Pay attention to costs, subscriptions and advertising.
tips.provider_transparency: Serious providers clearly explain what is paid and what is free.
tips.practice_only: Tip: Use apps to practise, not as your only learning path.

links.babbel: Language learning app with structured courses, partly subject to fees.
links.busuu: Language learning app with community features and exercises.

find_job.title: Find a job
find_job.description: Now you have the knowledge you need to take the next step and find your place in the German job market. Use the right job portals and be active. Every application helps you move forward. If you keep going, show initiative, and believe in yourself, your chances of finding a suitable job will increase.

tips.portal_focus: Each job portal has a different focus. Do not rely on just one platform.
tips.similar_positions: Do not search only for your job title, but also for similar positions. Some jobs have different names in Germany than in your home country.
tips.support_services: Use the support services offered by the Jobcenter and the Federal Employment Agency.
tips.hidden_market: Many jobs are not posted online. Asking employers directly can often lead to better results than online applications.
tips.internships: Also consider internships or trial work. Very often, this can lead to a permanent job.
tips.apply_anyway: Apply even if you do not meet 100% of the requirements.
tips.track_applications: Keep a list of your applications so you can easily see where you have already applied.

steps.register_portals: Register on job portals. Create a profile and upload your CV.
steps.use_ai: Use AI tools to create CV templates and cover letters.
steps.adapt_cv: Adapt your CV and cover letter to each job you apply for.
steps.search_routine: Search for new job openings two to three times per week and respond to any feedback or replies.
steps.google_companies: Use Google to find companies near you. Go there in person or call them.
